title: Edge Coloring
content:
A **2-coloring** of edges of the complete graph K_n.

We represent edges as unordered pairs using Sym2 (Fin n), and colors as Bool (true/false = red/blue).
mathContext: Uses Sym2 for symmetric pairs, avoiding the need to handle edge orientation.

title: Monochromatic Copy
content:
A complete graph K_n **has a monochromatic copy** of G under coloring c if there exists an embedding f : V ↪ Fin n and a color such that all edges of G map to edges of that color.

This is the key property that Ramsey numbers guarantee.

title: Ramsey's Theorem
content:
**Ramsey's Theorem**: For any finite graph G, there exists N such that any 2-coloring of K_N contains a monochromatic copy of G.

This foundational result guarantees that Ramsey numbers are well-defined.

title: Ramsey Number
content:
**R(G)** is the minimum n such that any 2-coloring of K_n contains a monochromatic copy of G.

For trees T on n vertices: n ≤ R(T) ≤ 2n - 2.

title: Tree Predicate
content:
A graph is a **tree** if it is connected and has exactly n-1 edges for n vertices.

Equivalently: connected and acyclic, or any two vertices connected by a unique path.

title: Maximum Degree
content:
**maxDegree(G)** = max{deg(v) : v ∈ V}

For trees: paths have Δ = 2, stars have Δ = n-1.

title: Path Graph
content:
A **path** P_n is a tree where every vertex has degree at most 2.

Paths have the minimum Ramsey number among trees: R(P_n) = n.

title: Star Graph
content:
A **star** S_n is a tree with one central vertex adjacent to all n-1 other vertices.

Stars have the maximum Ramsey number among trees: R(S_n) = 2n - 2.

title: Caterpillar Graph
content:
A **caterpillar** is a tree where removing all leaves yields a path.

Caterpillars interpolate between paths and stars in structure.

title: Path Ramsey Number
content:
**R(P_n) = n** for paths on n ≥ 2 vertices.

Paths are the 'easiest' trees to find monochromatically. K_{n-1} can be 2-colored without a monochromatic P_n.

title: Star Ramsey Number
content:
**R(S_n) = 2n - 2** for stars on n ≥ 2 vertices.

Stars are the 'hardest' trees. Finding a monochromatic star requires finding a high-degree vertex in one color.

title: Chvátal's Theorem (1977)
content:
**Chvátal's Bound**: For a tree T with max degree Δ,

R(T) ≤ (Δ - 1)(n - 1) + 1

This is tight for paths (Δ = 2 gives R ≤ n) but weak for stars (Δ = n-1).
mathContext: The bound depends on the maximum degree, capturing how 'star-like' the tree is.

title: Erdős-Burr Conjecture
content:
**Erdős Problem #547 / Burr's Conjecture**:

For any tree T on n vertices, R(T) ≤ 2n - 2.

This was proved for all sufficiently large n. The bound is tight: stars achieve R(S_n) = 2n - 2.

title: Bound Comparison
content:
**When is Chvátal better than 2n-2?**

Chvátal's bound (Δ-1)(n-1)+1 < 2n-2 iff Δ ≤ 2.

Thus Chvátal is only better for paths, not for any tree with a vertex of degree ≥ 3.

title: Main Result
content:
**Erdős Problem #547: SOLVED**

Answer: YES, R(T) ≤ 2n - 2 for all trees T on n vertices.

The bound is tight (achieved by stars).

title: Tree Ramsey Ordering
content:
**Ordering**: For all trees T on n vertices,

n ≤ R(T) ≤ 2n - 2

Paths achieve the minimum (n), stars achieve the maximum (2n-2).
